name: Corn grain, at conversion plant, 2022
description:
This process transports corn grain to the conversion plant. It does so using transportation modal allocation from the USDA Ethanol Backgrounder (2007), assuming this current allocation will apply in 2022. Distances for each mode are from a combination of references; still missing a good distance estimate for barge, but since the share of barge transportation is ~2%, the final result will not be sensititive to this parameter.Infrastructure impacts are included in this process by calling the Ecoinvent "transport" processes.
The production of corn grain feedstock utilized in this transport process allocates inputs to the stover and grain based on the amount of ethanol that can be produced from each co-product (so-called "EtOH allocation").

processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.

exchanges.description: assuming barge is for dry goods, barge tanker for liquid. This process relates to "average" (current) barges, even though emissions will presumably be considerably lower in 2022.  Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip).  Assumes 2005 modal allocation and distances apply to 2022.

This process uses European train data extrapolated to US by ecoinvent. This process relates to "average" (current) trains, even though emissions will presumably be considerably lower in 2022.  Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip).  Assumes 2005 modal allocation and distances apply to 2022.

This is the most stringest European emission standard for lorries, though presumably considerably higher than standards in place in 2022. Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip). Assumes 2005 modal allocation and distances apply to 2022.
